<Link id="l00055" /><CodeLine lineNumber="55"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00056" /><CodeLine lineNumber="56"><Highlight kind="comment">/// Checks memory dependences among accesses to the same underlying</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00057" /><CodeLine lineNumber="57"><Highlight kind="comment">/// object to determine whether there vectorization is legal or not (and at</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00058" /><CodeLine lineNumber="58"><Highlight kind="comment">/// which vectorization factor).</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00059" /><CodeLine lineNumber="59"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00060" /><CodeLine lineNumber="60"><Highlight kind="comment">/// Note: This class will compute a conservative dependence for access to</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00061" /><CodeLine lineNumber="61"><Highlight kind="comment">/// different underlying pointers. Clients, such as the loop vectorizer, will</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00062" /><CodeLine lineNumber="62"><Highlight kind="comment">/// sometimes deal these potential dependencies by emitting runtime checks.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00063" /><CodeLine lineNumber="63"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00064" /><CodeLine lineNumber="64"><Highlight kind="comment">/// We use the ScalarEvolution framework to symbolically evalutate access</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00065" /><CodeLine lineNumber="65"><Highlight kind="comment">/// functions pairs. Since we currently don&#39;t restructure the loop we can rely</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00066" /><CodeLine lineNumber="66"><Highlight kind="comment">/// on the program order of memory accesses to determine their safety.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00067" /><CodeLine lineNumber="67"><Highlight kind="comment">/// At the moment we will only deem accesses as safe for:</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00068" /><CodeLine lineNumber="68"><Highlight kind="comment">///  &#42; A negative constant distance assuming program order.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00069" /><CodeLine lineNumber="69"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00070" /><CodeLine lineNumber="70"><Highlight kind="comment">///      Safe: tmp = a&#91;i + 1&#93;;     OR     a&#91;i + 1&#93; = x;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00071" /><CodeLine lineNumber="71"><Highlight kind="comment">///            a&#91;i&#93; = tmp;                y = a&#91;i&#93;;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00072" /><CodeLine lineNumber="72"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00073" /><CodeLine lineNumber="73"><Highlight kind="comment">///   The latter case is safe because later checks guarantuee that there can&#39;t</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00074" /><CodeLine lineNumber="74"><Highlight kind="comment">///   be a cycle through a phi node (that is, we check that &quot;x&quot; and &quot;y&quot; is not</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00075" /><CodeLine lineNumber="75"><Highlight kind="comment">///   the same variable: a header phi can only be an induction or a reduction, a</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00076" /><CodeLine lineNumber="76"><Highlight kind="comment">///   reduction can&#39;t have a memory sink, an induction can&#39;t have a memory</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00077" /><CodeLine lineNumber="77"><Highlight kind="comment">///   source). This is important and must not be violated (or we have to</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00078" /><CodeLine lineNumber="78"><Highlight kind="comment">///   resort to checking for cycles through memory).</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00079" /><CodeLine lineNumber="79"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00080" /><CodeLine lineNumber="80"><Highlight kind="comment">///  &#42; A positive constant distance assuming program order that is bigger</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00081" /><CodeLine lineNumber="81"><Highlight kind="comment">///    than the biggest memory access.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00082" /><CodeLine lineNumber="82"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00083" /><CodeLine lineNumber="83"><Highlight kind="comment">///     tmp = a&#91;i&#93;        OR              b&#91;i&#93; = x</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00084" /><CodeLine lineNumber="84"><Highlight kind="comment">///     a&#91;i+2&#93; = tmp                      y = b&#91;i+2&#93;;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00085" /><CodeLine lineNumber="85"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00086" /><CodeLine lineNumber="86"><Highlight kind="comment">///     Safe distance: 2 x sizeof(a&#91;0&#93;), and 2 x sizeof(b&#91;0&#93;), respectively.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00087" /><CodeLine lineNumber="87"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00088" /><CodeLine lineNumber="88"><Highlight kind="comment">///  &#42; Zero distances and all accesses have the same size.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00089" /><CodeLine lineNumber="89"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00090" /><CodeLine lineNumber="90" lineLink="/docs/api/classes/llvm/memorydepchecker"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">class </Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"><a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/memorydepchecker/#a7610f9bf36472cdb43096b7bcafd0a89">MemoryDepChecker</a> &#123;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00091" /><CodeLine lineNumber="91"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">public</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal">:</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00092" /><CodeLine lineNumber="92" lineLink="/docs/api/classes/llvm/memorydepchecker/#adb2762f61b5d5d514cdb7f650e23f617"><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">typedef</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/pointerintpair">PointerIntPair&lt;Value &#42;, 1, bool&gt;</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/memorydepchecker/#adb2762f61b5d5d514cdb7f650e23f617">MemAccessInfo</a>;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00093" /><CodeLine lineNumber="93" lineLink="/docs/api/classes/llvm/memorydepchecker/#abc943f0e03dddf08da437eab00bcd8e6"><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">typedef</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/smallvector">SmallVector&lt;MemAccessInfo, 8&gt;</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/memorydepchecker/#abc943f0e03dddf08da437eab00bcd8e6">MemAccessInfoList</a>;</Highlight><Highlight kind="comment"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00094" /><CodeLine lineNumber="94"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Set of potential dependent memory accesses.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00095" /><CodeLine lineNumber="95" lineLink="/docs/api/classes/llvm/memorydepchecker/#a4eb0c14b923c59b75a82bc41e03c2575"><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">typedef</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/equivalenceclasses">EquivalenceClasses&lt;MemAccessInfo&gt;</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/memorydepchecker/#a4eb0c14b923c59b75a82bc41e03c2575">DepCandidates</a>;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00096" /><CodeLine lineNumber="96"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00097" /><CodeLine lineNumber="97"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Type to keep track of the status of the dependence check. The order of</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00098" /><CodeLine lineNumber="98"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// the elements is important and has to be from most permissive to least</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00099" /><CodeLine lineNumber="99"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// permissive.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00100" /><CodeLine lineNumber="100" lineLink="/docs/api/classes/llvm/memorydepchecker/#ac661dd363bcde8b1e9516390eff1c400"><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">enum class</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/memorydepchecker/#ac661dd363bcde8b1e9516390eff1c400">VectorizationSafetyStatus</a> &#123;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00101" /><CodeLine lineNumber="101"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// Can vectorize safely without RT checks. All dependences are known to be</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00102" /><CodeLine lineNumber="102"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// safe.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00103" /><CodeLine lineNumber="103" lineLink="/docs/api/classes/llvm/memorydepchecker/#ac661dd363bcde8b1e9516390eff1c400ac6eea0560cd6f377e78dff2c85cc9122"><Highlight kind="normal">    <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/memorydepchecker/#ac661dd363bcde8b1e9516390eff1c400ac6eea0560cd6f377e78dff2c85cc9122">Safe</a>,</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00104" /><CodeLine lineNumber="104"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// Can possibly vectorize with RT checks to overcome unknown dependencies.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00105" /><CodeLine lineNumber="105" lineLink="/docs/api/classes/llvm/memorydepchecker/#ac661dd363bcde8b1e9516390eff1c400ad1b0fb720d53739ff1265c71d6977de8"><Highlight kind="normal">    <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/memorydepchecker/#ac661dd363bcde8b1e9516390eff1c400ad1b0fb720d53739ff1265c71d6977de8">PossiblySafeWithRtChecks</a>,</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00106" /><CodeLine lineNumber="106"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// Cannot vectorize due to known unsafe dependencies.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00107" /><CodeLine lineNumber="107" lineLink="/docs/api/classes/llvm/memorydepchecker/#ac661dd363bcde8b1e9516390eff1c400ad3d57868b6ff9839eff631d2cc8acbce"><Highlight kind="normal">    <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/memorydepchecker/#ac661dd363bcde8b1e9516390eff1c400ad3d57868b6ff9839eff631d2cc8acbce">Unsafe</a>,</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00108" /><CodeLine lineNumber="108"><Highlight kind="normal">  &#125;;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00109" /><CodeLine lineNumber="109"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00110" /><CodeLine lineNumber="110"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Dependece between memory access instructions.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00111" /><CodeLine lineNumber="111" lineLink="/docs/api/structs/llvm/memorydepchecker/dependence"><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">struct </Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"><a href="/docs/api/structs/llvm/memorydepchecker/dependence/#a40efa3de48a570060d0db38b654d9ea3">Dependence</a> &#123;</Highlight><Highlight kind="comment"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00112" /><CodeLine lineNumber="112"><Highlight kind="comment">    /// The type of the dependence.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00113" /><CodeLine lineNumber="113" lineLink="/docs/api/structs/llvm/memorydepchecker/dependence/#ae336b0e8514b99a44e73c3e2494c3cea"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">enum</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> <a href="/docs/api/structs/llvm/memorydepchecker/dependence/#ae336b0e8514b99a44e73c3e2494c3cea">DepType</a> &#123;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00114" /><CodeLine lineNumber="114"><Highlight kind="normal">      </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// No dependence.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00115" /><CodeLine lineNumber="115" lineLink="/docs/api/structs/llvm/memorydepchecker/dependence/#ae336b0e8514b99a44e73c3e2494c3ceaae12470995d757ddbebbd627f397fe349"><Highlight kind="normal">      <a href="/docs/api/structs/llvm/memorydepchecker/dependence/#ae336b0e8514b99a44e73c3e2494c3ceaae12470995d757ddbebbd627f397fe349">NoDep</a>,</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00116" /><CodeLine lineNumber="116"><Highlight kind="normal">      </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// We couldn&#39;t determine the direction or the distance.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00117" /><CodeLine lineNumber="117" lineLink="/docs/api/structs/llvm/memorydepchecker/dependence/#ae336b0e8514b99a44e73c3e2494c3ceaa3d96a899c885f75def67055e4b486dab"><Highlight kind="normal">      <a href="/docs/api/structs/llvm/memorydepchecker/dependence/#ae336b0e8514b99a44e73c3e2494c3ceaa3d96a899c885f75def67055e4b486dab">Unknown</a>,</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00118" /><CodeLine lineNumber="118"><Highlight kind="normal">      </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// At least one of the memory access instructions may access a loop</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00119" /><CodeLine lineNumber="119"><Highlight kind="normal">      </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// varying object, e.g. the address of underlying object is loaded inside</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00120" /><CodeLine lineNumber="120"><Highlight kind="normal">      </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// the loop, like A&#91;B&#91;i&#93;&#93;. We cannot determine direction or distance in</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00121" /><CodeLine lineNumber="121"><Highlight kind="normal">      </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// those cases, and also are unable to generate any runtime checks.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00122" /><CodeLine lineNumber="122" lineLink="/docs/api/structs/llvm/memorydepchecker/dependence/#ae336b0e8514b99a44e73c3e2494c3ceaa006edf4988ecca6989849eb1e4b92662"><Highlight kind="normal">      <a href="/docs/api/structs/llvm/memorydepchecker/dependence/#ae336b0e8514b99a44e73c3e2494c3ceaa006edf4988ecca6989849eb1e4b92662">IndirectUnsafe</a>,</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00123" /><CodeLine lineNumber="123"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00124" /><CodeLine lineNumber="124"><Highlight kind="normal">      </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// Lexically forward.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00125" /><CodeLine lineNumber="125"><Highlight kind="normal">      </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00126" /><CodeLine lineNumber="126"><Highlight kind="normal">      </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// FIXME: If we only have loop-independent forward dependences (e.g. a</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00127" /><CodeLine lineNumber="127"><Highlight kind="normal">      </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// read and write of A&#91;i&#93;), LAA will locally deem the dependence &quot;safe&quot;</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00128" /><CodeLine lineNumber="128"><Highlight kind="normal">      </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// without querying the MemoryDepChecker.  Therefore we can miss</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00129" /><CodeLine lineNumber="129"><Highlight kind="normal">      </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// enumerating loop-independent forward dependences in</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00130" /><CodeLine lineNumber="130"><Highlight kind="normal">      </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// getDependences.  Note that as soon as there are different</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00131" /><CodeLine lineNumber="131"><Highlight kind="normal">      </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// indices used to access the same array, the MemoryDepChecker &#42;is&#42;</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00132" /><CodeLine lineNumber="132"><Highlight kind="normal">      </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// queried and the dependence list is complete.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00133" /><CodeLine lineNumber="133" lineLink="/docs/api/structs/llvm/memorydepchecker/dependence/#ae336b0e8514b99a44e73c3e2494c3ceaa0e2ea83a39804701390079f7d07ed112"><Highlight kind="normal">      <a href="/docs/api/structs/llvm/memorydepchecker/dependence/#ae336b0e8514b99a44e73c3e2494c3ceaa0e2ea83a39804701390079f7d07ed112">Forward</a>,</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00134" /><CodeLine lineNumber="134"><Highlight kind="normal">      </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// Forward, but if vectorized, is likely to prevent store-to-load</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00135" /><CodeLine lineNumber="135"><Highlight kind="normal">      </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// forwarding.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00136" /><CodeLine lineNumber="136" lineLink="/docs/api/structs/llvm/memorydepchecker/dependence/#ae336b0e8514b99a44e73c3e2494c3ceaaec0ae061c48cbea01461ccb40dbc4c7a"><Highlight kind="normal">      <a href="/docs/api/structs/llvm/memorydepchecker/dependence/#ae336b0e8514b99a44e73c3e2494c3ceaaec0ae061c48cbea01461ccb40dbc4c7a">ForwardButPreventsForwarding</a>,</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00137" /><CodeLine lineNumber="137"><Highlight kind="normal">      </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// Lexically backward.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00138" /><CodeLine lineNumber="138" lineLink="/docs/api/structs/llvm/memorydepchecker/dependence/#ae336b0e8514b99a44e73c3e2494c3ceaa4af323986f2ce2d7f10399fe8997096b"><Highlight kind="normal">      <a href="/docs/api/structs/llvm/memorydepchecker/dependence/#ae336b0e8514b99a44e73c3e2494c3ceaa4af323986f2ce2d7f10399fe8997096b">Backward</a>,</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00139" /><CodeLine lineNumber="139"><Highlight kind="normal">      </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// Backward, but the distance allows a vectorization factor of dependent</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00140" /><CodeLine lineNumber="140"><Highlight kind="normal">      </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// on MinDepDistBytes.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00141" /><CodeLine lineNumber="141" lineLink="/docs/api/structs/llvm/memorydepchecker/dependence/#ae336b0e8514b99a44e73c3e2494c3ceaa2a42f6e575ea09a8ee7c396bf3821b4d"><Highlight kind="normal">      <a href="/docs/api/structs/llvm/memorydepchecker/dependence/#ae336b0e8514b99a44e73c3e2494c3ceaa2a42f6e575ea09a8ee7c396bf3821b4d">BackwardVectorizable</a>,</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00142" /><CodeLine lineNumber="142"><Highlight kind="normal">      </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// Same, but may prevent store-to-load forwarding.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00143" /><CodeLine lineNumber="143" lineLink="/docs/api/structs/llvm/memorydepchecker/dependence/#ae336b0e8514b99a44e73c3e2494c3ceaa219afbca7ad4b6a18f20c507b7b12353"><Highlight kind="normal">      <a href="/docs/api/structs/llvm/memorydepchecker/dependence/#ae336b0e8514b99a44e73c3e2494c3ceaa219afbca7ad4b6a18f20c507b7b12353">BackwardVectorizableButPreventsForwarding</a></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00144" /><CodeLine lineNumber="144"><Highlight kind="normal">    &#125;;</Highlight></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00195" /><CodeLine lineNumber="195"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Check whether the dependencies between the accesses are safe.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00196" /><CodeLine lineNumber="196"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00197" /><CodeLine lineNumber="197"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Only checks sets with elements in \\p CheckDeps.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00198" /><CodeLine lineNumber="198"><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="keywordtype">bool</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/memorydepchecker/#a2e54d4cd15784b0f0480ca88bcf3165f">areDepsSafe</a>(</Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">const</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/memorydepchecker/#a4eb0c14b923c59b75a82bc41e03c2575">DepCandidates</a> &amp;AccessSets,</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00199" /><CodeLine lineNumber="199"><Highlight kind="normal">                   </Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">const</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/memorydepchecker/#abc943f0e03dddf08da437eab00bcd8e6">MemAccessInfoList</a> &amp;CheckDeps);</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00200" /><CodeLine lineNumber="200"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment"></Highlight></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00341" /><CodeLine lineNumber="341"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// accesses.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00342" /><CodeLine lineNumber="342"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00343" /><CodeLine lineNumber="343"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Access \\p A must happen before \\p B in program order. The two indices</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00344" /><CodeLine lineNumber="344"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// identify the index into the program order map.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00345" /><CodeLine lineNumber="345"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00346" /><CodeLine lineNumber="346"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// This function checks  whether there is a plausible dependence (or the</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00347" /><CodeLine lineNumber="347"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// absence of such can&#39;t be proved) between the two accesses. If there is a</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00348" /><CodeLine lineNumber="348"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// plausible dependence but the dependence distance is bigger than one</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00349" /><CodeLine lineNumber="349"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// element access it records this distance in \\p MinDepDistBytes (if this</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00350" /><CodeLine lineNumber="350"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// distance is smaller than any other distance encountered so far).</Highlight></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00615" /><CodeLine lineNumber="615"><Highlight kind="comment">/// Drive the analysis of memory accesses in the loop</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00616" /><CodeLine lineNumber="616"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00617" /><CodeLine lineNumber="617"><Highlight kind="comment">/// This class is responsible for analyzing the memory accesses of a loop.  It</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00618" /><CodeLine lineNumber="618"><Highlight kind="comment">/// collects the accesses and then its main helper the AccessAnalysis class</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00619" /><CodeLine lineNumber="619"><Highlight kind="comment">/// finds and categorizes the dependences in buildDependenceSets.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00620" /><CodeLine lineNumber="620"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00621" /><CodeLine lineNumber="621"><Highlight kind="comment">/// For memory dependences that can be analyzed at compile time, it determines</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00622" /><CodeLine lineNumber="622"><Highlight kind="comment">/// whether the dependence is part of cycle inhibiting vectorization.  This work</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00623" /><CodeLine lineNumber="623"><Highlight kind="comment">/// is delegated to the MemoryDepChecker class.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00624" /><CodeLine lineNumber="624"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00625" /><CodeLine lineNumber="625"><Highlight kind="comment">/// For memory dependences that cannot be determined at compile time, it</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00626" /><CodeLine lineNumber="626"><Highlight kind="comment">/// generates run-time checks to prove independence.  This is done by</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00627" /><CodeLine lineNumber="627"><Highlight kind="comment">/// AccessAnalysis::canCheckPtrAtRT and the checks are maintained by the</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00628" /><CodeLine lineNumber="628"><Highlight kind="comment">/// RuntimePointerCheck class.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00629" /><CodeLine lineNumber="629"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00630" /><CodeLine lineNumber="630"><Highlight kind="comment">/// If pointers can wrap or can&#39;t be expressed as affine AddRec expressions by</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00631" /><CodeLine lineNumber="631"><Highlight kind="comment">/// ScalarEvolution, we will generate run-time checks by emitting a</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00632" /><CodeLine lineNumber="632"><Highlight kind="comment">/// SCEVUnionPredicate.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00633" /><CodeLine lineNumber="633"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00634" /><CodeLine lineNumber="634"><Highlight kind="comment">/// Checks for both memory dependences and the SCEV predicates contained in the</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00635" /><CodeLine lineNumber="635"><Highlight kind="comment">/// PSE must be emitted in order for the results of this analysis to be valid.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00790" /><CodeLine lineNumber="790"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00791" /><CodeLine lineNumber="791"><Highlight kind="comment">/// Return the SCEV corresponding to a pointer with the symbolic stride</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00792" /><CodeLine lineNumber="792"><Highlight kind="comment">/// replaced with constant one, assuming the SCEV predicate associated with</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00793" /><CodeLine lineNumber="793"><Highlight kind="comment">/// \\p PSE is true.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00794" /><CodeLine lineNumber="794"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00795" /><CodeLine lineNumber="795"><Highlight kind="comment">/// If necessary this method will version the stride of the pointer according</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00796" /><CodeLine lineNumber="796"><Highlight kind="comment">/// to \\p PtrToStride and therefore add further predicates to \\p PSE.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00797" /><CodeLine lineNumber="797"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00798" /><CodeLine lineNumber="798"><Highlight kind="comment">/// \\p PtrToStride provides the mapping between the pointer value and its</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00799" /><CodeLine lineNumber="799"><Highlight kind="comment">/// stride as collected by LoopVectorizationLegality::collectStridedAccess.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00855" /><CodeLine lineNumber="855"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00856" /><CodeLine lineNumber="856"><Highlight kind="comment">/// Calculate Start and End points of memory access.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00857" /><CodeLine lineNumber="857"><Highlight kind="comment">/// Let&#39;s assume A is the first access and B is a memory access on N-th loop</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00858" /><CodeLine lineNumber="858"><Highlight kind="comment">/// iteration. Then B is calculated as:</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00859" /><CodeLine lineNumber="859"><Highlight kind="comment">///   B = A + Step&#42;N .</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00860" /><CodeLine lineNumber="860"><Highlight kind="comment">/// Step value may be positive or negative.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00861" /><CodeLine lineNumber="861"><Highlight kind="comment">/// N is a calculated back-edge taken count:</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00862" /><CodeLine lineNumber="862"><Highlight kind="comment">///     N = (TripCount &gt; 0) ? RoundDown(TripCount -1 , VF) : 0</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00863" /><CodeLine lineNumber="863"><Highlight kind="comment">/// Start and End points are calculated in the following way:</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00864" /><CodeLine lineNumber="864"><Highlight kind="comment">/// Start = UMIN(A, B) ; End = UMAX(A, B) + SizeOfElt,</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00865" /><CodeLine lineNumber="865"><Highlight kind="comment">/// where SizeOfElt is the size of single memory access in bytes.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00866" /><CodeLine lineNumber="866"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00867" /><CodeLine lineNumber="867"><Highlight kind="comment">/// There is no conflict when the intervals are disjoint:</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00868" /><CodeLine lineNumber="868"><Highlight kind="comment">/// NoConflict = (P2.Start &gt;= P1.End) || (P1.Start &gt;= P2.End)</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00869" /><CodeLine lineNumber="869"><Highlight kind="normal">std::pair&lt;const SCEV &#42;, const SCEV &#42;&gt; <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/#afdd1ebe6412f9afb43d0639420afffe0">getStartAndEndForAccess</a>(</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00870" /><CodeLine lineNumber="870"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">const</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> Loop &#42;Lp, </Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">const</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> SCEV &#42;PtrExpr, Type &#42;AccessTy, </Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">const</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> SCEV &#42;MaxBECount,</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00871" /><CodeLine lineNumber="871"><Highlight kind="normal">    ScalarEvolution &#42;SE,</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00872" /><CodeLine lineNumber="872"><Highlight kind="normal">    DenseMap&lt;std::pair&lt;const SCEV &#42;, Type &#42;&gt;,</Highlight></CodeLine>
